bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, August 1, 1892

div1.p: Alden requests that Reed be ordered to St. Paul, Minnesota, to provide medical care to officers, enlisted men, and families as well as to examine recruits. The letter, endorsements, and resulting order are dated from August 1, 1892 to August 18, 1892. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, August 1, 1892
div1.p:
Invites attention
to necessity of pro-
viding medical officer's
attendance for officers
& enl. men at these
headqrs. & their families
and to examine recruits
in this city, and re-
commends Capt. Walter
Reed, Asst Sug. be ordered
to this city for the duty.

ADJUTANT GENL'S OFFICE
RECEIVED
AUG 16 1892
A.C.P. DIVISION.

See letter to Col. Greenleaf,
Aug 3/92.

First Endorsement.
Headquarters Department of Dakota,
St. Paul, Minn. August 11, 1892.

Respectfully forwarded to the
Adjutant General, U.S. Army.

As the within communication
is an exposition of the state of
situation at these headquarters
it is forwarded for the informa-
tion of the proper authorities.
I have already expressed an
opinion on the hardship of leav-
ing men and officers at these
headquarters without proper med-
ical attendance.

Respectfully referred to the
Surgeon General

J. B. Eilman
Asst. Adjutant General.

Respectfully returned to the
Adjutant General of the Army,
with the recommendation that
upon the arrival of 1st Lieut
Charles F. Mason, Assistant Sur-
geon, at Fort Snelling, Minn.
Captain Walter Reed, Assistant
Surgeon, be relieved from duty
at that station, and ordered
to report in person to the
commanding general, Department
of Dakota, for duty as Attending
Surgeon and Examiner of Recruits
at the headquarters of that
department.

C Sutherland
Surgeon General
US Army

Approved: By order of
the Acting Secretary of War.

S.O. 194 Par. 10, AUG 1892.
A. G. Office.

div1.head: Letter from C. H. Alden to the Adjutant General, August 1, 1892
div1.opener:
3060 D2/SGO
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF DAKOTA.
MEDICAL DIRECTOR'S OFFICE,
RECEIVED
AUG. 16. 92
S.G.O.
ST. PAUL, MINN., August 1, 1892.
To the
Adjutant General of the Department.
Sir:-
div1.p:
The contract of Dr Park Ritchie, employed to attend officers and
enlisted men and their families and to examine recruits in this city,
having been necessarily terminated June 30, 1892, by failure of appropria-
tion, I have the honor to invite attention to the necessity of provision
being made for this service. During my absence on inspection duty at
posts in this Department from July 1st to 23rd, 1892, attendance was ren-
dered by private physicians under Par. 1636 A.R., but this since my return
to the city would seem not to be allowable. The impracticability of
the Medical Director of this Department doing the duties of attending
surgeon as required by A.R. 198 has been recognized in the past by the
employment of a contract surgeon for that purpose, and is apparent from
the following considerations. The number of officers and enlisted men,
including those retired, in this city is 54, the men, women and children
of their families 124, total 178. There are 28 families. No civilian
clerks nor their families nor the families of retired officers and men
are included. The enlisted men at this Headquarters are obliged for
sake of economy of rent to reside in the suburbs of the city, so that the
persons entitled to medical attendance are scattered over a wide area
some 10 miles square. The examination of recruits at the rendezvous
in this city, at which is enlisted it is believed more than at any other
single rendezvous in the country, requires at least one hour daily.

It is obvious that this considerable number of persons and so
widely scattered cannot be given proper medical attendance by the Med-
ical Director, who has the medical and sanitary oversight of 14 posts
and sub posts, whose time is fully occupied during the usual office hours,
has only one clerk to assist in the correspondence and keeping the
records required by the duties of his office and is necessarily absent a
considerable portion of the year on inspection duty.

As a third medical officer 1st Lieut. Mason, Asst. Surg., is under
orders for Fort Snelling, thus rendering the services of Captain Walter
Reed, Asst. Surg., available, I recommend that this latter officer be ordered
to this city for the duty indicated.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant, C. H. Alden. Lt. Col. and Surg. U.S.A.,
Medical Director.

div1.head: Special Orders, No. 194, August 18, 1892
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, August 18, 1892.

10. By direction of the acting Secretary of War Captain
Walter Reed, assistant surgeon, upon the arrival of 1st Lieu-
tenant Charles F. Mason, assistant surgeon, at Fort Snelling,
Minnesota, will be relieved from duty at that station and will
report in person to the commanding general Department of
Dakota for duty as attending surgeon and examiner of recruits
at the headquarters of that department. The travel enjoined is
necessary for the public service.

BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL SCHOFIELD:
R. WILLIAMS,
Adjutant General.
